title.narrative: Women's Leadership and Advocacy (WLAI)

description.narrative: WLAI seeks to address key socio-economic barriers affecting women’s potential to contribute to social, economic and political progress in South Sudan, as a basis for improving women’s quality of life, changing negative social norms, increasing women’s influence in decision-making processes, and enabling women’s economic empowerment. Based on CARE’s Strategy on Gender Equality and Women’s Voices and CARE’s Female Entrepreneurship Framework, WLAI will address the unequal power relations and access to resources and opportunities that affect South Sudanese women. WLAI will focus on the Juba and Torit Counties and will be implemented in coordination with leading women rights organisations, national parliamentarians, and key government agencies at the national, state and county levels. CARE’s support to WROs will strengthen their institutional and networking capacities, leveraging their potential to coordinate effective advocacy that will bring positive change to South Sudan.

title.narrative: Number of VSLA members (disaggregated by age and gender) trained in economic opportunities, economic rights and gender norms

comment.narrative: As part of the formation and revitalization of VSLA groups and in Q1, WAPO managed to identify and establish 9 VSLA groups. Each VSLA has 25 members. so a total of 225 members were reached during this reporting period. In the next quarter (Q2) more VSLA groups will be identified and trained.

title.narrative: Number of Women's Parliamentarian Caucus members trained in relevant thematic areas of policy analysis and advocacy

comment.narrative: CIGPJ was not able to conduct this activity in Q1 despite all the preparatory meetings with the government due to other government commitments. Key events included the Governors Forum and the 16 Days of Activities that were key priorities for the women caucus. Participants are mobilized and activities are scheduled to be implemented in Q2.

title.narrative: Number of Advocacy events organized by CSOs/WROs at the State and national level

comment.narrative: In Juba, CIGPJ held a press conference on 29th October to commemorate the 20th Anniversary of the Women Peace and Security (WPS) Agenda. CIGPJ joined other implementing agencies (UN and Government) to commemorate the 20th Anniversary of the United Nations Security Resolution (UNSCR) 1325 adopted in October 2000. A total of 23 participants including 18 Women-Led Organization (WLO) members and journalists from 5 different national media outlets attended the event including Juba Monitor, Eye Radio, City Review, City FM, and Classic FM.

title.narrative: Number of participants (disaggregated by gender) in State and national level conferences on 35% affirmative action and role of women in nation builiding

comment.narrative: In Juba, from 6th - 7th October, 2021 CARE and partners CIGPJ and WAPO organized a two-day Inception and Orientation Workshop in Juba. The event brought together 37 participants (26 females, 11 male) from among the WLOs. Similarly, in Torit, WAPO organized half-a- day “Tea Talk” to increase the understanding of Women, Peace and Security (WPS) and the status of the 35 affirmative action provision enshrined in the peace agreement. A total of 19 participants including 18 female and 1 male attended the event. The meeting was aimed at building effective coordination and networking, and to increase the targeted women's understanding of the UNSCR 1325 resolution. both events brought together a total of 56 participants.

title.narrative: Number of radio/TV dialogues on gender policy, women’s entrepreneurship and economic empowerment organised

comment.narrative: In October CIGPJ in Juba organized three radio talkshows on 35% affirmative action and women's leadership . These discussions took place on October 28th at Suma FM, on October 29th on Eye Radio and October 31st on Yei Radio Esther 94 FM.

title.narrative: Number of people reached via radio mass awareness campaigns on gender norms, women's rights, participation and leadership

comment.narrative: In October, CIGPJ orgnized three Radio talk on 35% affirmative Action on women leadership in Juba and Yei counties of Central Equatorial State . The discussion took place on 28th in Summer FM, and 29th on Eye radio, and 31 October 2021 on Radio Esther 94 FM in Yei. Overall, 9950 listeners were reached according to the estimates from the radio stations.

title.narrative: Number of youth/women (disaggregated by age and gender) engaged via career guidance and employment opportunity meetings at the State level

comment.narrative: In Torit, Eastern Equatorial State WAPO with funding from CARE though the WLAI project held a meeting to enrol women youth to vocational training centre has been initiated with the State Ministry of Education. This meeting was a preparation for the actual enrolment anticipated to is to kick off in the next semester (January 2022).

title.narrative: Number of men/boys reached via discussion sessions on positive masculinities and women's rights using the men engage/EMAP tool

comment.narrative: In Torit, WAPO conducted a meeting with community leaders to identify gender champions to advance women's rights and gender equality within their communities. The event was held on 28 October. During the discussion, there were groups of 7 men, 5 women, 7 male youths and 5 female youths . The male beneficiaries who were chosen as gender champions are men/male youth who are adamant to advance women's rights/ gender equality and also knowledgeable about issues affecting women, including GBV, in the community.

title.narrative: Number of public debates on 35% affirmative action aired on radio with support from WLAI

comment.narrative: In Yei County, Central Equatorial State, CIGPJ conducted one radio talk show to generate a debate on the status of the implementation of the 35% affirmative action on 31st October, 2021. The debate brought together 4 women penalists (two CIGPJ Staff and two volunteers from the WOMEN NETWORK in Yei) The panelists deliberated on the topic and members of the general public were given an opportunity to call in and contribute substantially to the discussion.

title.narrative: Number of CSOs/WROs provided with small grants to organize advocacy events on 35% affirmative action and women's participation and leadership at all levels

comment.narrative: The Centre for Inclusive Governance, Peace and Justice (CIGPJ) based in Juba and the Women Agency for Progress Organization (WAPO) were awarded subgrants to implement advocacy events on the 35% affirmative action at State and National Level.

title.narrative: Number of women leaders selected from existing/newly established networks trained in leadership, negotiation, coordination and communication skills

comment.narrative: Women leaders from the Women-Led Organizations (WLOs) and Women Rights Organizations (WROs) who are the targeted beneficiaries for this indicator were engaged in their respective organizations' activities during Q1. As such, training could not be delivered in September and October as originally planned. WAPO plans to conduct this activity in the next quarter (Q2). In the meantime, WAPO has started to mobilize the participants and has confirmed that thhis event will be conducted in this quarter to allow them to implement the other pending activities in the other remaining quarters. This strategy is intended to compensate for the lost time and allow the partners to accomplish all planned activities on time.
